About the PACE Satellite

PACE Mission

PACE (Plankton, Aerosol, Cloud, ocean Ecosystem) is a NASA satellite mission aimed at studying the interactions between the atmosphere and the ocean. The satellite launch is scheduled for 2024.

Primary Mission Goals:

  • Studying phytoplankton and its role in the global carbon cycle
  • Investigating aerosols and their impact on climate
  • Observing clouds and their interactions with aerosols
  • Monitoring the health of oceans and water quality

How PACE Collects Data

The PACE satellite is equipped with advanced instruments for data collection:

  • Ocean Color Instrument (OCI): A hyperspectral radiometer for measuring ocean color
  • Multi-angle Polarimeters: Two polarimeters for studying aerosols and clouds

Significance for Climate Change Studies

PACE data will help scientists better understand:

  • The role of oceans in the global carbon cycle
  • The impact of aerosols on cloud formation and climate
  • Changes in marine ecosystems and their consequences for the climate

About the project

PACE in the Classroom is an educational resource about the PACE satellite mission and the study of Earth's ecology.
